title: 109_hr988
content:
The Act may be cited as the "National Park Anniversaries-Great American Spaces Commemorative Coin Act". The National Park Foundation is the nonprofit partner of America's National Parks, aiming to strengthen the connection between the American people and their parks. The program includes beloved National Parks like Grand Canyon and Yosemite, managed by the National Park Service since 1916. Theodore Roosevelt emphasized the importance of leaving the land better for future generations. National Parks like Grand Canyon and Devils Tower are examples of this ideal. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $1 silver coins for National Parks, each weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, and containing 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Design requirements for the National Park $1 silver coins include consultation with the National Park Foundation, emblematic designs, value designation, year inscription, and specific words inscribed. The design selection process involves the Secretary, the Commission of Fine Arts, and the National Park Foundation. The National Parks to be commemorated under this Act will be reviewed by various committees and include specific design requirements. The National Parks commemorated under this Act include Devils Tower National Monument, Grand Canyon National Park, Glacier National Park, Lincoln Memorial, Yosemite National Park, Rocky Mountain National Park, National Park Service, Denali National Park, and Acadia National Park, all celebrating their respective anniversaries. In 2018, Acadia National Park celebrated its 100th anniversary. In 2019, Zion National Park also marked its 100th anniversary. In 2020, Gettysburg National Military Park commemorated its 125th anniversary. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. Only 1 facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike any particular quality of the coins. The Secretary may issue coins beginning January 1 of the year of issuance, as specified in section 4(c), and sales may start before that date. No coins shall be minted after December 31 of the year of issuance. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

(a) Sale Price.--Coins shall be sold at face value plus the cost of designing and issuing them.
(b) Bulk Sales.--Bulk sales will be offered at a discount.
(c) Prepaid Orders at a Discount.--Prepaid orders will be accepted before issuance at a reasonable discount.
(d) Sales of Single Coins and Sets.--Coins may be sold individually or as sets with other authorized coins.

SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. The sales of coins issued under this Act require a $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharges received will be promptly paid to the National Park Foundation, with 50% used to support all National Parks and 50% for specific designated Parks. The National Park Foundation will be subject to audit requirements. The National Park Foundation will be subject to audit requirements under section 5134(f)(2) of title 31, United States Code, for the amounts received under subsection (b). SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee from a depository institution.
